keyTakeAways: Sean Grayson, a 31-year-old Illinois sheriff’s deputy, is on trial for the first-degree murder of Sonya Massey, a 36-year-old Black woman, in her Springfield home on July 6, 2024, after she picked up a pan of hot water that Grayson claimed he interpreted as a threat.

Body camera footage shows that Grayson entered the home, ordered the removal of a hot water pan, and when Massey picked it up, he believed she intended to harm him and fired three shots, hitting her once below the left eye.

Massey, a single mother with a history of mental health struggles, had previously sought inpatient care and made multiple 911 calls expressing fear and distress, but Grayson was unaware of this history.

The incident prompted significant public outcry and led to a state-level reform in Illinois law requiring full disclosure of personal and employment background records for all prospective law enforcement candidates.
Grayson, who had a history of DUIs, military discharge for drunken driving, and poor performance evaluations in previous policing roles, was fired from his department after the incident and arrested.
Sangamon County Sheriff Jack Campbell retired six weeks after the shooting, and the trial was relocated to Peoria due to national attention and security concerns.

The trial has drawn attention to broader issues of police use of force, racial bias, and transparency in law enforcement hiring processes, especially in cases involving Black individuals in their homes.

The jury selection process emphasized juror attitudes toward law enforcement, with the state attorney asking whether jurors believed officers could use any level of force they deemed necessary—none responded affirmatively.
Defense attorney Dan Fultz focused on jurors’ personal comfort with returning a not guilty verdict and general attitudes toward personal obligations.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Sean Grayson, a 31-year-old Illinois sheriff’s deputy, is on trial for the first-degree murder of Sonya Massey, a 36-year-old Black woman, in her Springfield home on July 6, 2024. The shooting occurred after Grayson, responding to a report of a suspected prowler, believed Massey intended to harm him when she picked up a pan of hot water. Body camera footage shows Grayson pulled a gun and fired three shots, killing her. Massey had a documented history of mental health struggles and had made multiple 911 calls expressing fear, which Grayson was unaware of. Grayson’s history includes a DUI conviction, a military discharge for drunken driving, and poor performance evaluations in prior policing roles. The incident prompted widespread public outcry and led to a state law reform in Illinois requiring full background transparency for all law enforcement candidates. The trial was relocated to Peoria for security reasons, and jury selection began with focused questions about attitudes toward police use of force. The case has ignited national conversations about racial bias, mental health in policing, and accountability in law enforcement.
